results.title: 6.00 PM
results.credit_line: Tate: Purchased using funds provided by the 2006 Outset / Frieze Art Fair Fund to benefit the Tate Collection 2007
results.description: The title 6.00 PM implies that the pattern at the centre of the carpet depicts the play of light and shadow cast through a window at six o’clock in the evening. But the carpet is always displayed in a windowless gallery and the image itself never changes. We can walk across and leave marks on the carpet, meaning we are unlikely to be tricked by the illusion. By fixing a particular moment of light, the work draws attention to connections between light and our perception of time.
description_for_label: The title 6.00 PM implies that the pattern at the centre of the carpet depicts the play of light and shadow cast through a window at six o’clock in the evening. But the carpet is always displayed in a windowless gallery and the image itself never changes. We can walk across and leave marks on the carpet, meaning we are unlikely to be tricked by the illusion. By fixing a particular moment of light, the work draws attention to connections between light and our perception of time.
results.credit_line_for_label: Tate: Purchased using funds provided by the 2006 Outset / Frieze Art Fair Fund to benefit the Tate Collection 2007

results.title: Olympic Legacy: this was forever
results.creator_credit: Mark Aitken, First Light and Polkadotsonraindrops
results.brief_description: Set in East London, the location of the 2012 Olympics, this documentary follows a community’s battle to prevent their allotments being swallowed up in the development plans. This powerful film looks at what happens when a diverse group of people are united in despair about the effects of change.
results.description: Set in East London, the location of the 2012 Olympics, this documentary follows a community’s battle to prevent their allotments being swallowed up in the development plans. This powerful film looks at what happens when a diverse group of people are united in despair about the effects of change.

results.title: My Grandma
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Taylor, First Light, Smith and Watson Productions and Wide Eyed
results.brief_description: Jamie is a girl who just wants to enjoy herself. However, she is constantly called upon to care for her demanding Grandmother. She is tired of hearing tales of Grandma’s childhood whilst missing out on her own. Successfully demonstrating the difference between two generations of women, will her Grandma’s constant nagging and complaining push Jamie too far?
results.creator_credit_for_label: Geoffrey Taylor, First Light, Smith and Watson Productions and Wide Eyed

results.title: A Mile in our Shoes
results.creator_credit: Daniel Walker, Sarah Mortimer, Karl Armstrong, Steph Winward, First Light, Middlesbrough Football Club Study Support, Riverside Studios and The Junction
results.brief_description: The average age of a young carer in the UK is 12. This is a poignant and moving tribute to those many young carers tending to parents or siblings or both. They manage the domestic needs of a household as well as the physical needs of those they are caring for. They sometimes care for more than one family member with ailments ranging from autism to muscular dystrophy. With a constant lack of understanding from the rest of the world, no wonder there is little time for sleep let alone a social life.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Daniel Walker, Sarah Mortimer, Karl Armstrong, Steph Winward, First Light, Middlesbrough Football Club Study Support, Riverside Studios and The Junction

results.title: Destination Point
results.creator_credit: Argyle Primary School, Bloom Productions and First Light
results.brief_description: Year 5 Primary school pupils from Kings Cross explore the ethnic diversity of their area and school. Kings Cross is an international destination point. Thousands of people travel in and out of the station every day. Some are travelling through on their way to somewhere else, some come into work and others travel to Kings Cross and make it home.

results.title: The Box
results.creator_credit: Felix Drake, Patrick Young, Phoebe Flemming, eShed, First Light and Watershed
results.brief_description: This short drama is a tight observation of family life during the recession. Shot in a single living room, we see the ebb and flow of family life reflected in some pivotal moments through a particularly difficult time. However, the digital hearth remains a constant source of comfort.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Felix Drake, Patrick Young, Phoebe Flemming, eShed, First Light and Watershed

results.title: Beloved
results.creator_credit: Daniel Zinkant, Elle Farnham, First Light and Suited & Booted Studios
results.brief_description: Through the main protagonist Dave, we hear and see what it is like to be in love and have those feelings trapped inside. As we are let into Dave’s world, we see him and a group of friends as they leave school and embark on their journey home. The film flicks between two worlds of fantasy and real-life as the journey progresses. As the narrative comes to an end, we watch the three friends depart and Dave is left alone. His love unknown, unsaid but only understood by the viewer.

results.title: 'Screen It' 2012 - winners
results.brief_description:
‘Screen It’ was Australia’s national film, animation and game making competition for school-aged students, run by ACMI for 16 years to 2019.

Designed to encourage imagination and inventiveness in primary and secondary school students, ‘Screen It’ fostered a new generation of young media makers. In 2012, the theme, ‘Belonging’, attracted around 400 entries.

Nine winning entries were selected across the categories of live action, animation, computer game and a special section, titled “Bullying: no way”. While some films are about fitting in, many of them advocate embracing your unique identity and subsequently being accepted by others.

Witness first-hand the amazing winning entries of the 2012 Screen It competition!

results.title: You don't belong here [game trailer]
results.brief_description:
By staying true to your own ideals you will find a group of unique individuals where everyone belongs. A man is shipwrecked on a distant island. He must search the island for a tribe to live in by avoiding obstacles and collecting gems along the way. These tribes will take you in but on the condition you behave like them. You decline their offer saying you have a right to be yourself. You are then banished and must avoid members of these tribes as you continue your search. They attempt to catch you as you dont belong. Finally you come across a tribe that accepts you for who you are. They are all individuals and make you feel like you belong.

Under the category ‘Primary Videogames’, Liam Blake, Hope Valley, SA, was the Screen It 2012 winner.

results.title: Wish
results.creator_credit: Araine Moir, Elizabeth Kuiper and Emily Abernethy
results.brief_description:
A young girl is transported into a fantasy world where her birthday wishes manifest into something beyond her control. This film questions the importance we place on superficial and materialistic desires.

Under the category ‘Best Overall Secondary School Entry’, Year 12, Presbyterian Ladies’ College, Peppermint Grove, WA, were the Screen It 2012 winners.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Araine Moir, Elizabeth Kuiper and Emily Abernethy
